elements.content: A striking variety of anhydrous and hydrated ionic cocrystals (ICCs) of the enantiopure antiepileptic drug (AED) levetiracetam and of its racemic intermediate etiracetam with the pharmaceutically acceptable salts CaCl2 and MgCl2 was synthesized and structurally characterized. The difference in the interaction of enantiopure and racemic compounds of interest with the inorganic salts was investigated. Variable-temperature X-ray powder diffraction (VT-XRPD) and calorimetric analyses (TGA and DSC) of all obtained ICCs showed a significant improvement in thermal stability with respect to pure racetams.
elements.clean_text: A striking variety of anhydrous and hydrated ionic cocrystals (ICCs) of the enantiopure antiepileptic drug (AED) levetiracetam and of its racemic intermediate etiracetam with the pharmaceutically acceptable salts CaCl2 and MgCl2 was synthesized and structurally characterized. The difference in the interaction of enantiopure and racemic compounds of interest with the inorganic salts was investigated. Variable-temperature X-ray powder diffraction (VT-XRPD) and calorimetric analyses (TGA and DSC) of all obtained ICCs showed a significant improvement in thermal stability with respect to pure racetams.

elements.content: This work focuses on ionic cocrystallization of enantiopure LEV and racemic mixture ETI with inorganic salts CaCl2 and MgCl2. A diverse solid state landscape and chiral packing choice were demonstrated, and all the ionic cocrystals showed a significant increase in the thermal stability with respect to the parent organic systems.
elements.clean_text: This work focuses on ionic cocrystallization of enantiopure LEV and racemic mixture ETI with inorganic salts CaCl2 and MgCl2. A diverse solid state landscape and chiral packing choice were demonstrated, and all the ionic cocrystals showed a significant increase in the thermal stability with respect to the parent organic systems.

elements.content: Epilepsy is a prevailing chronic neurological disorder or a group of disorders characterized by unprompted seizures that tend to recur. More than 50 million people worldwide are affected by this condition. Levetiracetam ((S)-2-(2-oxopyrrolidin-1-yl)­butanamide, ) is the active pharmaceutical ingredient (API) of KEPPRA, an antiepileptic drug (AED) commercialized by UCB Pharma. Levetiracetam is one of the most recent AEDs that has been approved by Food and Drug Administration in 1999.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Epilepsy is a prevailing chronic neurological disorder or a group of disorders characterized by unprompted seizures that tend to recur. More than 50 million people worldwide are affected by this condition. Levetiracetam ((S)-2-(2-oxopyrrolidin-1-yl)butanamide, ) is the active pharmaceutical ingredient (API) of KEPPRA, an antiepileptic drug (AED) commercialized by UCB Pharma. Levetiracetam is one of the most recent AEDs that has been approved by Food and Drug Administration in 1999.

elements.content: Etiracetam is encountered as a racemic intermediate in the synthesis of levetiracetam. The racemic compound contains, besides the active S-enantiomer (levetiracetam) of pharmaceutical interest, (R)-etiracetam, which does not exert the desired biological properties.
elements.clean_text: Etiracetam is encountered as a racemic intermediate in the synthesis of levetiracetam. The racemic compound contains, besides the active S-enantiomer (levetiracetam) of pharmaceutical interest, (R)-etiracetam, which does not exert the desired biological properties.

elements.content: Ionic cocrystals (ICCs) are multicomponent crystalline solid forms composed of neutral organic molecules and salts in a defined stoichiometric ratio. Due to their potentially more effective capacity to alter in a desired way the physicochemical properties of interest (e.g., solubility, intrinsic dissolution rate, bioavailability, morphology, hygroscopicity, and thermal stability), ICCs are increasingly attracting the attention of the scientific community. Cocrystals in general, and ICCs in particular, are of enormous interest for the pharmaceutical industry since they can provide an alternative route to new pharmaceutical formulations compared to conventional salts. Particularly, the formation of cocrystals can be of use if the API of interest has no ionizable moieties, such as the compounds discussed in this work. In the absence of ionizable groups and consequent salt formation, molecular cohesion is usually enhanced in molecular cocrystals by hydrogen and/or halogen bonds and π–π stacking, whereas Coulombic forces (ion–ion and ion–dipole) are also at work and dominant in ICCs. Besides their possible effect on the physicochemical properties of the API, cocrystals have potential implications on intellectual property issues.
elements.clean_text: Ionic cocrystals (ICCs) are multicomponent crystalline solid forms composed of neutral organic molecules and salts in a defined stoichiometric ratio. Due to their potentially more effective capacity to alter in a desired way the physicochemical properties of interest (e.g., solubility, intrinsic dissolution rate, bioavailability, morphology, hygroscopicity, and thermal stability), ICCs are increasingly attracting the attention of the scientific community. Cocrystals in general, and ICCs in particular, are of enormous interest for the pharmaceutical industry since they can provide an alternative route to new pharmaceutical formulations compared to conventional salts. Particularly, the formation of cocrystals can be of use if the API of interest has no ionizable moieties, such as the compounds discussed in this work. In the absence of ionizable groups and consequent salt formation, molecular cohesion is usually enhanced in molecular cocrystals by hydrogen and/or halogen bonds and π-π stacking, whereas Coulombic forces (ion-ion and ion-dipole) are also at work and dominant in ICCs. Besides their possible effect on the physicochemical properties of the API, cocrystals have potential implications on intellectual property issues.

elements.content: Cocrystallization of chiral molecules has been extensively studied by our groups and has proven to be a useful approach for the chiral resolution of racemic mixtures. We showed that the application of (S)-mandelic acid as a coformer allows to resolve a racemic solution of etiracetam via selective formation of cocrystals with the S-enantiomerthe enantiomer that possesses antiepileptic activity. Although this approach resembles the conventional method of chiral resolution by salt formation, cocrystals between the coformer (S)-mandelic acid and the opposite enantiomer ((R)-etiracetam with (S)-mandelic acid) could not be obtained, once more highlighting the differences of cocrystals with respect to salts.
elements.clean_text: Cocrystallization of chiral molecules has been extensively studied by our groups and has proven to be a useful approach for the chiral resolution of racemic mixtures. We showed that the application of (S)-mandelic acid as a coformer allows to resolve a racemic solution of etiracetam via selective formation of cocrystals with the S-enantiomerthe enantiomer that possesses antiepileptic activity. Although this approach resembles the conventional method of chiral resolution by salt formation, cocrystals between the coformer (S)-mandelic acid and the opposite enantiomer ((R)-etiracetam with (S)-mandelic acid) could not be obtained, once more highlighting the differences of cocrystals with respect to salts.

elements.content: Quite unexpectedly, ICC formation has been found to offer an additional tool for chiral resolution, as recently discovered for the ionic cocrystals of alkali and alkaline earth halides with the amino acids dl-histidine and dl-proline. The use of lithium halides results in a marked preference for Li+ to selectively link the amino acids of only one chirality, with formation either of conglomerates or of racemic crystals constituted of homochiral chains.
elements.clean_text: Quite unexpectedly, ICC formation has been found to offer an additional tool for chiral resolution, as recently discovered for the ionic cocrystals of alkali and alkaline earth halides with the amino acids dl-histidine and dl-proline. The use of lithium halides results in a marked preference for Li+ to selectively link the amino acids of only one chirality, with formation either of conglomerates or of racemic crystals constituted of homochiral chains.

elements.content: Recently we showed for the first time that, in the cocrystallization of levetiracetam and etiracetam with ZnCl2, the stoichiometry ratio could be used to reversibly switch between a racemic compound and a conglomerate.
elements.clean_text: Recently we showed for the first time that, in the cocrystallization of levetiracetam and etiracetam with ZnCl2, the stoichiometry ratio could be used to reversibly switch between a racemic compound and a conglomerate.

elements.content: In this Article, we take the ICC approach further, and cocrystallize both enantiopure and racemic etiracetam with inorganic salts accepted by the pharmacopoeia, i.e., CaCl2 and MgCl2. Taking into account the relatively low melting points of the pure racetams (116 and 119 °C for the enantiopure and the racemic compounds, respectively), it was expected that, upon cocrystallization with the inorganic salts, thermal stability enhancement could be achieved. This assumption was supported by our previous study of ICCs of brivaracetam and seletracetam with calcium and magnesium chlorides. In the present case, we also wanted to explore the behavior of racemic vs. enantiopure pharmaceuticals in ICCs of alkaline earth with respect to that observed with alkali metal salts, with a particular focus on the thermal stability of the compounds in the solid state.

This assumption was supported by our previous study of ICCs of brivaracetam and seletracetam with calcium and magnesium chlorides. In the present case, we also wanted to explore the behavior of racemic vs. enantiopure pharmaceuticals in ICCs of alkaline earth with respect to that observed with alkali metal salts, with a particular focus on the thermal stability of the compounds in the solid state.

elements.content: (S)-2-(2-Oxopyrrolidin-1-yl)­butanamide (levetiracetam) was purchased from Xiamen Top Health Biochem Tech. Co., Ltd. (R,S)-2-(2-Oxopyrrolidin-1-yl)­butanamide (etiracetam) was prepared by racemization of (S)-2-(2-oxopyrrolidin-1-yl)­butanamide. Ten grams of (S)-2-(2-oxopyrrolidin-1-yl)­butanamide together with a catalytic amount (0.05 equiv) of MeONa were added to 10 mL of methanol. The solution was kept under reflux and continuous stirring for 24 h, then cooled to room temperature. The compound crystallizes spontaneously. After filtration, the compound was washed twice with methanol and used as such. All other reagents were purchased from Sigma and used without purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

(S)-2-(2-Oxopyrrolidin-1-yl)butanamide (levetiracetam) was purchased from Xiamen Top Health Biochem Tech. Co., Ltd. (R,S)-2-(2-Oxopyrrolidin-1-yl)butanamide (etiracetam) was prepared by racemization of (S)-2-(2-oxopyrrolidin-1-yl)butanamide. Ten grams of (S)-2-(2-oxopyrrolidin-1-yl)butanamide together with a catalytic amount (0.05 equiv) of MeONa were added to 10 mL of methanol. The solution was kept under reflux and continuous stirring for 24 h, then cooled to room temperature. The compound crystallizes spontaneously. After filtration, the compound was washed twice with methanol and used as such. All other reagents were purchased from Sigma and used without purification.

elements.content: All samples were prepared by dissolution of the starting materials API/MX2 (API = LEV or ETI and MX2= CaCl2 or MgCl2) in 1:1, 2:1, and 4:1 stoichiometric ratios in ethanol, methanol, or water; the solution was left to evaporate at room temperature. In some cases, single crystals were directly obtained from solution; in other cases, the slow evaporation brought about the formation of oils, and single crystals were obtained from these oils, left standing in the air at ambient conditions for 1 to 10 days. The results are shown in .
elements.clean_text:
Solution Experiments

All samples were prepared by dissolution of the starting materials API/MX2 (API = LEV or ETI and MX2= CaCl2 or MgCl2) in 1:1, 2:1, and 4:1 stoichiometric ratios in ethanol, methanol, or water; the solution was left to evaporate at room temperature. In some cases, single crystals were directly obtained from solution; in other cases, the slow evaporation brought about the formation of oils, and single crystals were obtained from these oils, left standing in the air at ambient conditions for 1 to 10 days. The results are shown in .

elements.content:
ICCs Obtained by Reacting Etiracetam (ETI) and Levetiracetam (LEV) with CaCl<sub>2</sub> and MgCl<sub>2</sub> ICCmethod LEV:CaCl2 1:1, 2:1, 4:1 LEV2·CaCl2·2H2OLAG, sl, sol ETI:CaCl2 1:1, 2:1, 4:1 ETI2·CaCl2·2H2OLAG, sl, sol LEV:MgCl2 1:1, 2:1, 4:1 LEV2·MgCl2·2H2OLAG, sl, sol ETI:MgCl2 1:1 ETI2·MgCl2·6H2OLAG, sl, sol ETI4·MgCl2·6H2Osl ETI2·MgCl2·2H2OHSM ETI:MgCl2 2:1 ETI4·MgCl2·4H2OLAG ETI4·MgCl2·6H2Osl, sol ETI:MgCl2 4:1 ETI4·MgCl2·6H2OLAG, sol

No results from solution. LAG = liquid assisted grinding; sl = slurry; sol = evaporation from solution; HSM = hot stage microscopy.

All slurry experiments were performed by stirring aqueous suspensions of the starting materials in 1:1, 2:1, and 4:1 stoichiometric ratios of API/MX2. The total mass of starting materials was 100 mg. The amount of water was set at 80 μL for the CaCl2 experiments, and at 60 μL for the MgCl2 experiments. The suspensions were seeded with starting materials and corresponding cocrystals and stirred at 25 °C over 48 h to make sure that the system reached thermodynamic equilibrium. Then samples were filtered over sintered glass, followed by XRPD analysis of the solid phases. The results are shown in .
elements.clean_text:
Slurry Experiments

All slurry experiments were performed by stirring aqueous suspensions of the starting materials in 1:1, 2:1, and 4:1 stoichiometric ratios of API/MX2. The total mass of starting materials was 100 mg. The amount of water was set at 80 μL for the CaCl2 experiments, and at 60 μL for the MgCl2 experiments. The suspensions were seeded with starting materials and corresponding cocrystals and stirred at 25 °C over 48 h to make sure that the system reached thermodynamic equilibrium. Then samples were filtered over sintered glass, followed by XRPD analysis of the solid phases. The results are shown in .

elements.content: Powder samples can be obtained mechanochemically through LAG of different stoichiometric mixtures of LEV or ETI and CaCl2 or MgCl2 with the addition of 10 μL of methanol. The sample was ground in a RETSCH Mixer Mill MM 400 for 90 min with a beating frequency of 30 Hz. The results are shown in . ETI4·MgCl2·4H2O was obtained by LAG of ETI and MgCl2 (2 to 1) for 60 min in a Retsch MM200 ball miller, operated at a frequency of 25 Hz, in the presence of a few drops of methanol.
elements.clean_text:
Liquid Assisted Grinding (LAG)

Powder samples can be obtained mechanochemically through LAG of different stoichiometric mixtures of LEV or ETI and CaCl2 or MgCl2 with the addition of 10 μL of methanol. The sample was ground in a RETSCH Mixer Mill MM 400 for 90 min with a beating frequency of 30 Hz. The results are shown in . ETI4⋅MgCl2⋅4H2O was obtained by LAG of ETI and MgCl2 (2 to 1) for 60 min in a Retsch MM200 ball miller, operated at a frequency of 25 Hz, in the presence of a few drops of methanol.

elements.content: Single crystals of ETI2·MgCl2·2H2O were obtained using HSM. The measurements were carried out using a Linkam TMS94 device connected to a Linkam LTS350 platinum plate. The powder of ETI2·MgCl2·6H2O was put in fomblin. The sample was heated up to 110 °C and kept at this temperature for 30 min. The sample was then slowly cooled down (5 °C/min) to room temperature, and the obtained crystals were analyzed.
elements.clean_text:
Hot Stage Microscopy (HSM)

Single crystals of ETI2⋅MgCl2⋅2H2O were obtained using HSM. The measurements were carried out using a Linkam TMS94 device connected to a Linkam LTS350 platinum plate. The powder of ETI2⋅MgCl2⋅6H2O was put in fomblin. The sample was heated up to 110 °C and kept at this temperature for 30 min. The sample was then slowly cooled down (5 °C/min) to room temperature, and the obtained crystals were analyzed.

elements.content: Data collection was carried out in an Oxford X’Calibur S CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator (Mo–Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature and a MAR345 using monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) (Xenocs Fox3D mirror) produced by a Rigaku UltraX18S rotating anode at room temperature. Refinement details are listed in . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. HNH and part of the HOH atoms were located from difference Fourier maps and refined. HCH and the remaining HOH atoms were added in calculated positions and refined riding on their respective C and O atoms. SHELX-2014 was used for all structure solutions and refinements on F2.
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Diffraction (SCXRD)

Data collection was carried out in an Oxford X'Calibur S CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator (Mo-Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature and a MAR345 using monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) (Xenocs Fox3D mirror) produced by a Rigaku UltraX18S rotating anode at room temperature. Refinement details are listed in . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. HNH and part of the HOH atoms were located from difference Fourier maps and refined. HCH and the remaining HOH atoms were added in calculated positions and refined riding on their respective C and O atoms. SHELX-2014 was used for all structure solutions and refinements on F2.

X-ray powder diffraction data were collected with a PANalytical X’Pert Pro and on a Siemens D5000 diffractometer equipped with a Cu X-ray source operating at 40 kV and 40 mA and the secondary monochromator allowing to select the Kα radiation of Cu (λ = 1.5418 Å). A scanning range of 2θ values from 5° to 50° at a scan rate of 0.6° min–1 was applied. VT-XRPD diffractograms were collected in the 5–50° 2θ range on a PANalytical X’Pert PRO automated diffractometer, equipped with an X’Celerator detector and an Anton Paar TTK 450 system for measurements at controlled temperature. Data were collected in the open air in Bragg–Brentano geometry, using Cu–Kα radiation without a monochromator. Thermal programs were selected on the basis of TGA results.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Powder Diffraction (XRPD) and Variable-Temperature X-ray Powder Diffraction (VT-XRPD)

X-ray powder diffraction data were collected with a PANalytical X'Pert Pro and on a Siemens D5000 diffractometer equipped with a Cu X-ray source operating at 40 kV and 40 mA and the secondary monochromator allowing to select the Kα radiation of Cu (λ = 1.5418 Å). A scanning range of 2θ values from 5° to 50° at a scan rate of 0.6° min-1 was applied. VT-XRPD diffractograms were collected in the 5-50° 2θ range on a PANalytical X'Pert PRO automated diffractometer, equipped with an X'Celerator detector and an Anton Paar TTK 450 system for measurements at controlled temperature. Data were collected in the open air in Bragg-Brentano geometry, using Cu-Kα radiation without a monochromator. Thermal programs were selected on the basis of TGA results.

elements.content: The reactivity of both levetiracetam and etiracetam (in the following LEV and ETI, respectively) with calcium and magnesium chlorides was investigated by three different methods, namely, liquid assisted grinding (LAG, also called kneading), slurry, and solvent slow evaporation of undersaturated solutions. The latter method inevitably led to the formation of viscous oils, irrespective of the solvent used (water, methanol, or ethanol) from which solids precipitated in a period ranging from 1 to 10 days. The solids were identified as ICCs. Liquid-assisted grinding was performed with methanol as solvent, while water was utilized for the slurry experiments. Different stoichiometric ratios were employed to check for all the possible cocrystal forms and to determine the most stable forms. The main results are listed in . Stoichiometric excess of CaCl2 or MgCl2 was never detected in X-ray powder diffraction patterns, as these salts are deliquescent and contribute only to the background.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The reactivity of both levetiracetam and etiracetam (in the following LEV and ETI, respectively) with calcium and magnesium chlorides was investigated by three different methods, namely, liquid assisted grinding (LAG, also called kneading), slurry, and solvent slow evaporation of undersaturated solutions. The latter method inevitably led to the formation of viscous oils, irrespective of the solvent used (water, methanol, or ethanol) from which solids precipitated in a period ranging from 1 to 10 days. The solids were identified as ICCs. Liquid-assisted grinding was performed with methanol as solvent, while water was utilized for the slurry experiments. Different stoichiometric ratios were employed to check for all the possible cocrystal forms and to determine the most stable forms. The main results are listed in . Stoichiometric excess of CaCl2 or MgCl2 was never detected in X-ray powder diffraction patterns, as these salts are deliquescent and contribute only to the background.

elements.content: shows a surprising difference in behavior depending on the nature of the inorganic salt used. The number of accessible forms, the nature of the racemate, the stoichiometry, and the hydration of the final ICCs are all markedly dependent on the nature of the salt. For this reason, the peculiarities of the interaction of the investigated racetams with each inorganic salt will be discussed in detail to attempt a rationale for this variety.

elements.content: Cocrystallization of calcium chloride with racemic mixture ETI and LEV appeared to be quite straightforward. In both cases, only one crystalline form of ICC was detected, regardless of the solvent or the method applied (). Single crystals for the LEV and ETI ICCs could be obtained both from solution and from the melt and were characterized as hydrates of formula LEV2·CaCl2·2H2O and ETI2·CaCl2·2H2O. Regardless of the application of different stoichiometric ratios, we always got the same ICC, along with the excess of unreacted starting material. The racemic and the enantiopure ICCs are quasi-isostructural ( and ) due to the position of the chiral center in ETI molecule not directly involved in the crystal packing, which will be discussed in detail.
elements.clean_text:
Cocrystals of Levetiracetam and Etiracetam with CaCl2 

Cocrystallization of calcium chloride with racemic mixture ETI and LEV appeared to be quite straightforward. In both cases, only one crystalline form of ICC was detected, regardless of the solvent or the method applied (). Single crystals for the LEV and ETI ICCs could be obtained both from solution and from the melt and were characterized as hydrates of formula LEV2⋅CaCl2⋅2H2O and ETI2⋅CaCl2⋅2H2O. Regardless of the application of different stoichiometric ratios, we always got the same ICC, along with the excess of unreacted starting material. The racemic and the enantiopure ICCs are quasi-isostructural ( and ) due to the position of the chiral center in ETI molecule not directly involved in the crystal packing, which will be discussed in detail.

elements.content: (a) Coordination around the Ca2+ cation in crystalline LEV2·CaCl2·2H2O and ETI2·CaCl2·2H2O. (b) Single 2D-layer of Ca2+ ions, coordinated water, and racetam molecules extending in the ab-plane in crystalline LEV2·CaCl2·2H2O and ETI2·CaCl2·2H2O; (c) parallel 2D-layers projected down the b-axis in both ICCs. In addition to the strong Coulombic component, hydrogen bonds (not shown for clarity) are at work between the chloride ions and the NH2 (amide) groups/water molecules. Water oxygens are in blue; gray and orange spheres for ETI2·CaCl2·2H2O refer to racetams with opposite chirality; HCH atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Coordination around the Ca2+ cation in crystalline LEV2⋅CaCl2⋅2H2O and ETI2⋅CaCl2⋅2H2O. (b) Single 2D-layer of Ca2+ ions, coordinated water, and racetam molecules extending in the ab-plane in crystalline LEV2⋅CaCl2⋅2H2O and ETI2⋅CaCl2⋅2H2O; (c) parallel 2D-layers projected down the b-axis in both ICCs. In addition to the strong Coulombic component, hydrogen bonds (not shown for clarity) are at work between the chloride ions and the NH2 (amide) groups/water molecules. Water oxygens are in blue; gray and orange spheres for ETI2⋅CaCl2⋅2H2O refer to racetams with opposite chirality; HCH atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: In both hydrated ICCs LEV2·CaCl2·2H2O and ETI2·CaCl2·2H2O, an octahedral coordination is observed around the metal cation (a), comprising the oxygens of four different molecules of LEV (two oxygens of amide group and two of pyrrolidinone) and two water molecules. Each LEV interacts in turn with a second Ca2+ ion through its amide and pyrrolidinone groups, resulting in a 2:1 stoichiometry and a 2D-layered structures (b). Parallel layers (c) are connected to each other via hydrogen bonds between chlorides and amide NH2 groups or water molecules (Tables S1 and S2). It is noteworthy that the calcium complexation is enantioselective in the racemic crystal of ETI2·CaCl2·2H2O. c right shows how the crystal is composed of distinct chains of R-ETI and S-ETI (LEV), as observed in crystalline LEV2·CaCl2·2H2O. Superposition of the R-ETI layer onto the LEV layer reveals that the overall layer conformation is kept and that the molecules are able to adapt themselves to the local change in chirality (Figure SI-1). This packing choice is reminiscent of what is systematically observed on crystals of the amino acids dl-histidine and dl-proline with alkali and alkaline earth halides.

Each LEV interacts in turn with a second Ca2+ ion through its amide and pyrrolidinone groups, resulting in a 2:1 stoichiometry and a 2D-layered structures (b). Parallel layers (c) are connected to each other via hydrogen bonds between chlorides and amide NH2 groups or water molecules (Tables S1 and S2). It is noteworthy that the calcium complexation is enantioselective in the racemic crystal of ETI2⋅CaCl2⋅2H2O. c right shows how the crystal is composed of distinct chains of R-ETI and S-ETI (LEV), as observed in crystalline LEV2⋅CaCl2⋅2H2O. Superposition of the R-ETI layer onto the LEV layer reveals that the overall layer conformation is kept and that the molecules are able to adapt themselves to the local change in chirality (Figure SI-1). This packing choice is reminiscent of what is systematically observed on crystals of the amino acids dl-histidine and dl-proline with alkali and alkaline earth halides.

elements.content: To study the thermal stability of the ICCs, VT-XRPD studies were performed. At room temperature, the XRPD pattern of LEV2·CaCl2·2H2O corresponds to the simulated pattern obtained from single crystal data. Upon heating LEV2·CaCl2·2H2O, a number of events are observed. The TGA trace shows a steady weight loss () up to 80 °C, which can easily be attributed to adsorbed surface water, an observable for all ICCs discussed and due to the hygroscopicity of the obtained ICCs. Between 90 and 130 °C a loss of 6.6% in weight corresponds to the loss of the 2 equiv of water of the dihydrate (theoretical weight loss = 7.5%), as also confirmed by VT-XRPD ( ). This anhydrous form remains stable up to 240 °C, temperature at which a transformation to a second anhydrous form occurs, followed by degradation. If the heating is stopped right before degradation occurs, and the sample is cooled back to room temperature, the initial LEV2·CaCl2·2H2O is again obtained.

elements.content: The thermal behavior of ETI2·CaCl2·2H2O ( and ) is similar to that of LEV2·CaCl2·2H2O. At room temperature, the XRPD pattern of ETI2·CaCl2·2H2O corresponds to the simulated pattern obtained from single crystal data. Surface water is lost up to 80 °C (when the sample is left for prolonged periods at 80 °C, cooled to 25 °C under nitrogen flow and reheated, one no longer observes the endotherms related to the evaporation of the surface water, Figures SI-8 and SI-9). The dehydration process starts above 140 °C () and corresponds to the loss of two water molecules (7.3% aligns with the theoretical loss of 7.5%). The dihydrate of the racemic compound thus has a higher thermal stability compared to that of the enantiopure compound. No further changes in the crystal phase of the anhydrate are observed up to its degradation occurring at 230 °C. If the anhydrate is cooled to room temperature, the initial dihydrate ICC is again obtained.

elements.content: Cocrystallization of LEV with MgCl2 led to the formation of LEV2·MgCl2·2H2O, which is isomorphous with the CaCl2 analogue (). As in the case of the ICC with CaCl2, only one stoichiometry was observed, irrespective of the starting stoichiometric ratio, solvent used, and method employed to obtain the cocrystals (). The thermal behavior ( and ) parallels the one observed for LEV2·CaCl2·2H2O, with surface water removal up to 100 °C and a single dehydration process observed at ca. 150 °C (experimental weight loss by TGA = 8.6% ; theoretical weight loss = 7.6%); the anhydrate phase thus obtained remains stable up to 240 °C. If the dehydration process is followed via HSM, melting is observed for the anhydrous phase at 240 °C, and recrystallization of the melt under ambient conditions yields the dihydrated ICC LEV2·MgCl2·2H2O.
elements.clean_text:
Cocrystals of Levetiracetam with MgCl2 

Cocrystallization of LEV with MgCl2 led to the formation of LEV2⋅MgCl2⋅2H2O, which is isomorphous with the CaCl2 analogue (). As in the case of the ICC with CaCl2, only one stoichiometry was observed, irrespective of the starting stoichiometric ratio, solvent used, and method employed to obtain the cocrystals (). The thermal behavior ( and ) parallels the one observed for LEV2⋅CaCl2⋅2H2O, with surface water removal up to 100 °C and a single dehydration process observed at ca. 150 °C (experimental weight loss by TGA = 8.6% ; theoretical weight loss = 7.6%); the anhydrate phase thus obtained remains stable up to 240 °C. If the dehydration process is followed via HSM, melting is observed for the anhydrous phase at 240 °C, and recrystallization of the melt under ambient conditions yields the dihydrated ICC LEV2⋅MgCl2⋅2H2O.

elements.content: Cocrystallization of racemic mixture ETI with MgCl2 leads to a more complex solid state landscape, with the outcome being dependent on reaction and stoichiometric conditions (). Different stoichiometries are obtained, namely, ETI2·MgCl2·6H2O (2:1 system) and ETI4·MgCl2·6H2O (4:1 system), and the cocrystals are hexahydrates, contrary to the dihydrates observed for all other cases. Thermal dehydration processes will lead to intermediate hydrate phases, as will be discussed below.
elements.clean_text:
Cocrystals of Etiracetam with MgCl2 

Cocrystallization of racemic mixture ETI with MgCl2 leads to a more complex solid state landscape, with the outcome being dependent on reaction and stoichiometric conditions (). Different stoichiometries are obtained, namely, ETI2⋅MgCl2⋅6H2O (2:1 system) and ETI4⋅MgCl2⋅6H2O (4:1 system), and the cocrystals are hexahydrates, contrary to the dihydrates observed for all other cases. Thermal dehydration processes will lead to intermediate hydrate phases, as will be discussed below.

elements.content: Reaction of ETI with MgCl2 in 1:1 stoichiometry, with the intent of obtaining ETI2·MgCl2·2H2O, i.e., the CaCl2 analogue, yielded an oil, which in a matter of a few days crystallized into the hexa-hydrated ICC of formula ETI2·MgCl2·6H2O (). The Mg2+ cation is hexacoordinated by two pyrrolidinone oxygensbelonging to ETI R- and S-enantiomersand by four water molecules, thus forming a 0D complex instead of the 1D chains encountered in the previously discussed ICCs. The amido groups are hydrogen bonded to the chloride anions and to water molecules via the −NH2 and −CO moieties, respectively (Table S4).
elements.clean_text:
The 2:1 System - ICC ETI2⋅MgCl2⋅nH2O (n = 2, 6)

Reaction of ETI with MgCl2 in 1:1 stoichiometry, with the intent of obtaining ETI2⋅MgCl2⋅2H2O, i.e., the CaCl2 analogue, yielded an oil, which in a matter of a few days crystallized into the hexa-hydrated ICC of formula ETI2⋅MgCl2⋅6H2O (). The Mg2+ cation is hexacoordinated by two pyrrolidinone oxygensbelonging to ETI R- and S-enantiomersand by four water molecules, thus forming a 0D complex instead of the 1D chains encountered in the previously discussed ICCs. The amido groups are hydrogen bonded to the chloride anions and to water molecules via the -NH2 and -CO moieties, respectively (Table S4).

elements.content: Upon heating, three subsequent transitions occur. A first transition occurs at around 70 °C, a second at 100 °C, and a third at 130 °C. TGA trace and VT-XRPD patterns ( and ) confirm that each step corresponds to the loss of two water molecules (21.6% total weight loss, theoretical loss of six water molecules = 19.9%). Degradation occurs starting from 250 °C. Based on this analysis, it can be inferred that a hexa-hydrate, a tetra-hydrate, a dihydrate, and an anhydrate phase exist for the 2:1 cocrystal.

elements.content: In addition to the hexahydrate ETI2·MgCl2·6H2O ICC, single crystals of the dihydrated ETI2·MgCl2·2H2O could also be obtained, as the product of recrystallization of ETI2·MgCl2·6H2O from the melt in a hot stage microscopy experiment, in a similar approach to the one employed to produce single crystals of LEV2·CaCl2·2H2O from the melt (SI-Hot Stage Microscopy experiment). The obtained crystals were analyzed and shown to be isomorphous with the calcium analogue ETI2·CaCl2·2H2O (). On the basis of the crystal structure of the hexahydrate and the dihydrate, we can conclude that the three successive water losses of the hexahydrate upon heating correspond to the loss of the water molecules not bound to the Mg2+ cation, followed by the loss of two of the four Mg2+ bound water molecules and finally to the last two Mg2+ bound water molecules of the dihydrate.
elements.clean_text: In addition to the hexahydrate ETI2⋅MgCl2⋅6H2O ICC, single crystals of the dihydrated ETI2⋅MgCl2⋅2H2O could also be obtained, as the product of recrystallization of ETI2⋅MgCl2⋅6H2O from the melt in a hot stage microscopy experiment, in a similar approach to the one employed to produce single crystals of LEV2⋅CaCl2⋅2H2O from the melt (SI-Hot Stage Microscopy experiment). The obtained crystals were analyzed and shown to be isomorphous with the calcium analogue ETI2⋅CaCl2⋅2H2O (). On the basis of the crystal structure of the hexahydrate and the dihydrate, we can conclude that the three successive water losses of the hexahydrate upon heating correspond to the loss of the water molecules not bound to the Mg2+ cation, followed by the loss of two of the four Mg2+ bound water molecules and finally to the last two Mg2+ bound water molecules of the dihydrate.

elements.content:
Cocrystallization from water of ETI with MgCl2, this time in a 4:1 stoichiometric ratio, yielded the hexahydrate ICC ETI4·MgCl2·6H2O ().

As for the 2:1 cocrystal, an octahedral coordination is observed around the Mg2+ cation with two molecules of ETI (both R- and S-enantiomers) and four water molecules forming a 0D complex. In the 4:1 cocrystal ETI4·MgCl2·6H2O, only the oxygens of pyrrolidinone are involved in the coordination with Mg2+, whereas the amide groups of ETI form CO···NH hydrogen bonds (b). One peculiarity of this structure is the presence of layers of ETI (R- and S-enantiomers) uncoordinated to Mg2+ cations. These ETI molecules form 1D chains via hydrogen bonds with water molecules coordinated to Mg2+ (c). These chains are held together via hydrogen bonds between amide groups and via NH2···Cl– and HOH···Cl– hydrogen bonds (Table S6). The ETI4·MgCl2·6H2O ICC could thus be seen as a “cocrystal” of ETI2·MgCl2·6H2O and ETI. Grinding of ETI4·MgCl2·6H2O with one equivalent of MgCl2, indeed, leads to ETI2·MgCl2·6H2O, whereas grinding of the latter with 2 equiv of ETI leads to ETI4·MgCl2·6H2O.
elements.clean_text:
The 4:1 System - ICCs ETI4⋅MgCl2⋅nH2O (n = 4,6)

Cocrystallization from water of ETI with MgCl2, this time in a 4:1 stoichiometric ratio, yielded the hexahydrate ICC ETI4⋅MgCl2⋅6H2O ().

As for the 2:1 cocrystal, an octahedral coordination is observed around the Mg2+ cation with two molecules of ETI (both R- and S-enantiomers) and four water molecules forming a 0D complex. In the 4:1 cocrystal ETI4⋅MgCl2⋅6H2O, only the oxygens of pyrrolidinone are involved in the coordination with Mg2+, whereas the amide groups of ETI form CO⋅⋅⋅NH hydrogen bonds (b). One peculiarity of this structure is the presence of layers of ETI (R- and S-enantiomers) uncoordinated to Mg2+ cations. These ETI molecules form 1D chains via hydrogen bonds with water molecules coordinated to Mg2+ (c). These chains are held together via hydrogen bonds between amide groups and via NH2⋅⋅⋅Cl- and HOH⋅⋅⋅Cl- hydrogen bonds (Table S6). The ETI4⋅MgCl2⋅6H2O ICC could thus be seen as a "cocrystal" of ETI2⋅MgCl2⋅6H2O and ETI. Grinding of ETI4⋅MgCl2⋅6H2O with one equivalent of MgCl2, indeed, leads to ETI2⋅MgCl2⋅6H2O, whereas grinding of the latter with 2 equiv of ETI leads to ETI4⋅MgCl2⋅6H2O.

Water molecules are marked in blue, Mg2+ cations are marked in orange, the carbon atoms of ETI molecules that are not involved into coordination with Mg2+ are marked in violet, hydrogens are omitted for clarity, and dashed lines are hydrogen bonds.

elements.content: VT-XRPD patterns and TGA trace ( and ) show the loss of two water molecules from ETI4·MgCl2·6H2O between 80 and 100 °C (4.3% weight loss, theoretical w% = 4.1). Four further H2O molecules are lost between 120 and 160 °C (7.8% weight loss, theoretical w% = 8.2). The weight loss between 160 and 200 °C is caused by the loss of 2 equiv of ETI, which is not coordinated to the Mg2+ cation (41.4% weight loss, theoretical w% = 38.5). The resulting ETI2·MgCl2 anhydrate form remains stable up to 245 °C.

elements.content: As shown above, the combination of ETI and MgCl2 leads to multiple hydrate forms. Slurry experiments () performed at 25 °C show the hexahydrate forms ETI2·MgCl2·6H2O and ETI4·MgCl2·6H2O to be the most stable phases in water at 25 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Stability Tests for ETI ICCs with MgCl2 

As shown above, the combination of ETI and MgCl2 leads to multiple hydrate forms. Slurry experiments () performed at 25 °C show the hexahydrate forms ETI2⋅MgCl2⋅6H2O and ETI4⋅MgCl2⋅6H2O to be the most stable phases in water at 25 °C.

elements.content: The interaction of enantiopure LEV and racemic ETI with the pharmaceutically acceptable inorganic salts CaCl2 and MgCl2 was investigated. It was found that both ETI and LEV formed crystalline dihydrates with CaCl2, namely, ETI2·CaCl2·2H2O and LEV2·CaCl2·2H2O, which possess similar structures and lead to anhydrates at temperatures above 120 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The interaction of enantiopure LEV and racemic ETI with the pharmaceutically acceptable inorganic salts CaCl2 and MgCl2 was investigated. It was found that both ETI and LEV formed crystalline dihydrates with CaCl2, namely, ETI2⋅CaCl2⋅2H2O and LEV2⋅CaCl2⋅2H2O, which possess similar structures and lead to anhydrates at temperatures above 120 °C.

elements.content: The interaction with MgCl2 led to a complex solid state landscape. While the enantiopure LEV produced only one ICC isostructural with LEV2·CaCl2·2H2O, the cocrystallization with ETI led to the formation of multiple crystalline phases. The crystallization from slurry and solutions typically led to formation of stoichiometrically diverse ETI2·MgCl2·6H2O or ETI4·MgCl2·6H2O cocrystals. The 4:1 cocrystal can be seen as a cocrystal between the 2:1 phase and ETI, with the interconversion illustrated by grinding experiments. Both hexahydrate phases lead to tetra-, dihydrate, and anhydrate phases upon heating. It is noteworthy that ETI2·MgCl2·2H2O, which is isostructural with ETI2·CaCl2·2H2O, shows the same type of homochiral preference for etiracetam molecules of the same chirality (S-ETI and R-ETI) upon complexation with the Ca2+ cations.

While the enantiopure LEV produced only one ICC isostructural with LEV2⋅CaCl2⋅2H2O, the cocrystallization with ETI led to the formation of multiple crystalline phases. The crystallization from slurry and solutions typically led to formation of stoichiometrically diverse ETI2⋅MgCl2⋅6H2O or ETI4⋅MgCl2⋅6H2O cocrystals. The 4:1 cocrystal can be seen as a cocrystal between the 2:1 phase and ETI, with the interconversion illustrated by grinding experiments. Both hexahydrate phases lead to tetra-, dihydrate, and anhydrate phases upon heating. It is noteworthy that ETI2⋅MgCl2⋅2H2O, which is isostructural with ETI2⋅CaCl2⋅2H2O, shows the same type of homochiral preference for etiracetam molecules of the same chirality (S-ETI and R-ETI) upon complexation with the Ca2+ cations.

elements.content: All cocrystals showed a significant increase in the thermal stability of both LEV and ETI in the ICCs with respect to the parent organic systems. All ICCs underwent dehydration and showed thermal stability up to 240–260 °C.

cln_elements.content: All slurry experiments were performed by stirring aqueous suspensions of the starting materials in 1:1, 2:1, and 4:1 stoichiometric ratios of API/MX2. The total mass of starting materials was 100 mg. The amount of water was set at 80 μL for the CaCl2 experiments, and at 60 μL for the MgCl2 experiments. The suspensions were seeded with starting materials and corresponding cocrystals and stirred at 25 °C over 48 h to make sure that the system reached thermodynamic equilibrium. Then samples were filtered over sintered glass, followed by XRPD analysis of the solid phases. The results are shown in .
cln_elements.clean_text:
Slurry Experiments

All slurry experiments were performed by stirring aqueous suspensions of the starting materials in 1:1, 2:1, and 4:1 stoichiometric ratios of API/MX2. The total mass of starting materials was 100 mg. The amount of water was set at 80 μL for the CaCl2 experiments, and at 60 μL for the MgCl2 experiments. The suspensions were seeded with starting materials and corresponding cocrystals and stirred at 25 °C over 48 h to make sure that the system reached thermodynamic equilibrium. Then samples were filtered over sintered glass, followed by XRPD analysis of the solid phases. The results are shown in .

cln_elements.content:
To study the thermal stability of the ICCs, VT-XRPD studies were performed. At room temperature, the XRPD pattern of LEV2·CaCl2·2H2O corresponds to the simulated pattern obtained from single crystal data. Upon heating LEV2·CaCl2·2H2O, a number of events are observed. The TGA trace shows a steady weight loss () up to 80 °C, which can easily be attributed to adsorbed surface water, an observable for all ICCs discussed and due to the hygroscopicity of the obtained ICCs. Between 90 and 130 °C a loss of 6.6% in weight corresponds to the loss of the 2 equiv of water of the dihydrate (theoretical weight loss = 7.5%), as also confirmed by VT-XRPD ( ). This anhydrous form remains stable up to 240 °C, temperature at which a transformation to a second anhydrous form occurs, followed by degradation. If the heating is stopped right before degradation occurs, and the sample is cooled back to room temperature, the initial LEV2·CaCl2·2H2O is again obtained.

Upon heating, three subsequent transitions occur. A first transition occurs at around 70 °C, a second at 100 °C, and a third at 130 °C. TGA trace and VT-XRPD patterns ( and ) confirm that each step corresponds to the loss of two water molecules (21.6% total weight loss, theoretical loss of six water molecules = 19.9%). Degradation occurs starting from 250 °C. Based on this analysis, it can be inferred that a hexa-hydrate, a tetra-hydrate, a dihydrate, and an anhydrate phase exist for the 2:1 cocrystal.

VT-XRPD patterns and TGA trace ( and ) show the loss of two water molecules from ETI4·MgCl2·6H2O between 80 and 100 °C (4.3% weight loss, theoretical w% = 4.1). Four further H2O molecules are lost between 120 and 160 °C (7.8% weight loss, theoretical w% = 8.2). The weight loss between 160 and 200 °C is caused by the loss of 2 equiv of ETI, which is not coordinated to the Mg2+ cation (41.4% weight loss, theoretical w% = 38.5). The resulting ETI2·MgCl2 anhydrate form remains stable up to 245 °C.

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>ICCs of LEV and ETI with CaCl<sub>2</sub>
</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr2" orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="cg-2019-00136s_0017.tif" xlink:type="simple"></graphic>
</fig>
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  ICCs of LEV and ETI with CaCl2

cln_elements.content: (a) Coordination around the Ca2+ cation in crystalline LEV2·CaCl2·2H2O and ETI2·CaCl2·2H2O. (b) Single 2D-layer of Ca2+ ions, coordinated water, and racetam molecules extending in the ab-plane in crystalline LEV2·CaCl2·2H2O and ETI2·CaCl2·2H2O; (c) parallel 2D-layers projected down the b-axis in both ICCs. In addition to the strong Coulombic component, hydrogen bonds (not shown for clarity) are at work between the chloride ions and the NH2 (amide) groups/water molecules. Water oxygens are in blue; gray and orange spheres for ETI2·CaCl2·2H2O refer to racetams with opposite chirality; HCH atoms are omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Coordination around the Ca2+ cation in crystalline LEV2⋅CaCl2⋅2H2O and ETI2⋅CaCl2⋅2H2O. (b) Single 2D-layer of Ca2+ ions, coordinated water, and racetam molecules extending in the ab-plane in crystalline LEV2⋅CaCl2⋅2H2O and ETI2⋅CaCl2⋅2H2O; (c) parallel 2D-layers projected down the b-axis in both ICCs. In addition to the strong Coulombic component, hydrogen bonds (not shown for clarity) are at work between the chloride ions and the NH2 (amide) groups/water molecules. Water oxygens are in blue; gray and orange spheres for ETI2⋅CaCl2⋅2H2O refer to racetams with opposite chirality; HCH atoms are omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content: VT-XRPD for LEV2·CaCl2·2H2O measured at different temperatures showing the transition to a high temperature form above 240 °C.
